comments.body: This seems to be incorrect, as the docs seem to say they are in the public domain: https://dejavu-fonts.github.io/License.html

hm... this was taken over like that from AnacondaRecipes and looked correct. Seems like Dejavu fonts are based on multiple previous fonts (all `BSD` licensed) plus the dejavu work on top, which is `public domain`. Now also changed the meta.yaml to `license: Public Domain, BSD-3-Clause`, `license_family: OTHER`. Hope that is more correct. The included LICENSE file is anyway stating this all correct.
Hmm it isn't BSD actually though. It can't be if it is public domain. And you shouldn't have a license file, per se, except maybe a copy of the website

Please read the link you pasted carefully and compare most of the text with a BSD license. Apart from the part that states:

> DejaVu changes are in public domain

The rest of this license is *very clearly* BSD-a-like, we could call it BSD + public domain, but the fact is, public domain stuff can (and often is) relicensed as BSD and that is fine (actually it is very much the point of public domain - do what you will).

> And you shouldn't have a license file, per se ..

Except for where it states: "The above copyright and trademark notices and this permission notice shall be included in all copies of one or more of the Font Software typefaces. "

We should use the license file from the link.

I don't think public domain works like that though. Specifically, public domain (in the US) is the absence of a copyright or other IP claims.  It doesn't make sense for something to BSD + public domain.  BSD still requires the original copyright to be listed. 

> We should use the license file from the link.

Yep agreed

I disagree and [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-domain_software) seems to as well:

> Paradoxically, his copyleft approach relies on the enforceability of the copyright to be effective. Copyleft free software shares therefore many properties with public-domain software, but doesn't allow relicensing or sublicensing. Unlike real public-domain software or permissive-licensed software, Stallman's copyleft license tries to enforce the free shareability of software also for the future by not allowing license changes.
And many projects routinely copy public domain code into them and relicense it (by that very act).
So I think that Deja Vu fonts are BSD-3 licensed, basically (and this was my thinking and research at the time).
I am a little confused. I am saying that this is BSD licensed, under the notion that public domain works can be licensed as BSD later.  @mingwandroid - can you please clarify?

We, as packagers/distributors have the same rights as developers of projects to relicense things where that is allowed by the respective licenses (or, lack of them), but I don't much care, call it BSD + public domain if that's your preference. Discussing licenses isn't really something I particularly enjoy I'm afraid, so I'll stop now.

edit: I thought you were arguing the opposite, well, call it BSD then, great!
Ok Sounds good! Seems like we agree :wink:
So what do we do? Reverting the last commit (which makes it `license: Public Domain, BSD-3-Clause`) and sticking to BSD ... or keeping it as it is?
Please change it to be just "BSD" with no public domain listing
